entry.title: Combined summary - tx max fee
entry.summary: The Bitcoin-dev mailing list has been discussing changing the "max fee" rule to output amounts in a transaction. The proposal is met with skepticism as it may result in more transactions and higher fees overall. Additionally, paying more fees than outputs can incentivize honest mining during state-level censorship attacks. However, one developer suggests preparing all transactions upfront, signing them, and broadcasting them all at once to avoid maintaining balances and using change addresses. They also mention the possibility of using HD wallets and algorithms to deterministically recreate the whole transaction tree. On May 7th, 2023, Erik Aronesty via bitcoin-dev proposed changing the maximum fee for transactions, but Peter Todd argues against this proposal, stating that it would negatively impact applications such as his OpenTimestamps service. Todd also notes that with Child Pays for Parent (CPFP), a transaction may need to have a larger fee than the output amounts. The proposal to change the maximum fee for transactions continues to be a topic of debate within the bitcoin-dev community. Finally, vjudeu proposed a new method of replacing transactions with multiple smaller transactions. The proposal sparked discussion among members of the bitcoin development community, with some expressing concern about the potential impact on the network's mempool and block size. Overall, these discussions highlight the ongoing innovation and experimentation within the world of cryptocurrency development.
